title.narrative: ECD KNOWLEDGE AND SKILLS OF PARENTS

description.narrative: By 2021, parents and families have enhanced knowledge and skills on nutrition, care, protection and development of young children, which contributes to Cross-Sectoral Early Childhood Development, Health And Development In Early Childhood And Adolescence. UNICEF aims to achieve this through Community Engagement, Social And Behaviour Change, Operational Support To Programme Delivery, Systems Strengthening And Institution Building, Systems Strengthening To Leave No One Behind. This contributes to the following Country Programme result: By 2021, children between the ages 0 to 5 years are progressively cared for through quality Early Child Development (ECD) services and in protective and nurturing family environments.

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: By 2021, parents and families have enhanced knowledge and skills on nutrition, care, protection and development of young children

description.narrative: In 2021, UNICEF supported parental engagement initiatives directly reaching 43,716 parents and caregivers, mostly through digital engagement via the Early Moment Matters on Mobile (EMMM) services. Onsite activities conducted through the ECD centres and health care providers were delayed and struggled, especially as these transitioned to online or hybrid modes due to closure of ECD centres. 10,655 children under five years of age - from extremely poor households, urban slums, and migrant families - were directly reached with play-based learning materials and storybooks (Magic Box), which helped families to positively engage and support their children’s development during extended closures.;; | Status:Constrained | As-of Date:30/01/2022
